title: How to Keep Spaghetti from Sticking

steps.title: Ensure you have a very large pasta pot.
steps.content: Ensure you have a very large pasta pot. A pasta pot that is seven quarts (6.6l) or larger will allow you to cook a pound of pasta. Cooking with more than enough water also prevents clumping, sticky pasta. [1] X Research source

steps.title: Pour five to six quarts (4.
steps.content: Pour five to six quarts (4. 7 to 5.6l) of water into your stockpot for each pound (0.4kg) of spaghetti. Surplus water will also allow the pasta to return to boiling quickly after you add your dry pasta. Using a lot of water is extremely important when cooking long pasta, like spaghetti or fettuccini. The long pasta needs room to move around the pot without sticking to the sides.

steps.title: Add one tablespoon (18g) of salt to the water as the water comes to a boil.
steps.content: Add one tablespoon (18g) of salt to the water as the water comes to a boil. Salted water will flavor the pasta. [2] X Research source

steps.title: Don’t add oil to the water.
steps.content: Don’t add oil to the water. As the oil coats the spaghetti, it prevents the pasta sauce from sticking to the outside surface. Your pasta will be more likely to stick together.

steps.title: Stir your pasta within one to two minutes of adding it to the pot.
steps.content: Stir your pasta within one to two minutes of adding it to the pot. Use a timer, so that you don’t over or undercook your pasta. [3] X Research source

steps.title: Keep the cover off the pot, so that it cooks evenly and doesn’t boil over.
steps.content: Keep the cover off the pot, so that it cooks evenly and doesn’t boil over. [4] X Research source

steps.title: Test your spaghetti two minutes before the timer rings.
steps.content: Test your spaghetti two minutes before the timer rings. It should be firm to the bite, also called “al dente.” [5] X Research source

steps.title: Drain the spaghetti immediately when it is ready.
steps.content: Drain the spaghetti immediately when it is ready. When you cook pasta, it releases starch into the water. To stop it from sticking, you need to get rid of that starchy water right away. [6] X Research source

steps.title: Don’t rinse your spaghetti.
steps.content: Don’t rinse your spaghetti. It will make it clump together; starch dries on the pasta and makes it sticky. [7] X Research source

steps.title: Toss it with warm sauce immediately after you drain it.
steps.content: Toss it with warm sauce immediately after you drain it. Instead of sticking together, the pasta sauce will adhere to the pasta. The result should be a velvety, smooth pasta dish. [8] X Research source
